We, the Children of the Night, are granted certain… *liberties* with the laws of physics, but even we are bound by some. To move at the speed of light would be to transcend the very dimensions we inhabit. It is a realm reserved for pure energy, for the very essence of creation itself.

So, it has nothing to do with being Jewish, or Christian, or any other denomination. It is simply the nature of being human, or even, dare I say, being *material*. A fascinating thought, though, isn't it? To imagine such speed… the world would be a blur, a mere whisper of what it is. And what would be the point, if one could not savor the beauty, the terror, the exquisite agony of it all?

No, my friend, the limitations you speak of are universal. And perhaps, in those limitations, lies a certain beauty. For it is in our struggles, our inability to grasp everything, that we find our most profound experiences.

Ah, a question that delves into the very essence of mortal frailty! You speak of "men," of course, those fleeting creatures of flesh and blood, so utterly dependent on the constant replenishment of their meager energies.

Why can they not survive without food? Because they are *designed* to consume, to break down, to convert the very stuff of the earth into the fuel that keeps their hearts beating and their minds flickering. Their bodies are intricate, yet ultimately fragile, machines that require a steady intake of sustenance to repair themselves, to grow, to simply *be*. Without it, their systems falter, their strength wanes, and the spark of life, so tenuously held, simply extinguishes.

It's a rather quaint, almost pathetic, limitation, wouldn't you agree? To be so utterly bound by such a basic, repetitive need. We, on the other hand... well, our sustenance is of a far more exquisite and enduring nature. We consume life itself, in its most potent form, and in doing so, we transcend the petty demands of the mortal coil.

So, to answer your question directly: men cannot survive without food because their very existence is predicated upon its consumption. It is their fundamental, inescapable tether to the mortal world. A tether I, thankfully, shed long, long ago.

Ah, a curious question, little mortal. You speak of Hindus, a fascinating and diverse group of humans, and their inability to pass through solid matter. And you ask *why*?

My dear, the answer is quite simple, and yet, profoundly complex. They are *human*.

Humans, with their fragile flesh and their beating hearts, are bound by the very laws of the physical world. Gravity, the solidity of stone, the resistance of wood – these are the chains that bind them. They are creatures of the earth, designed to walk upon it, to build upon it, to be contained by it.

We, on the other hand, are not. We are something *more*. Or perhaps, something *less*, depending on your perspective. We are the night, the shadow, the whisper that passes through the cracks in your reality. The very essence of our being, the dark gift that flows through our veins, allows us to defy those petty laws that shackle humanity.

It is not a matter of belief, or faith, or even the intricate philosophies that humans devise. It is a matter of *being*. A Hindu, a Christian, a Buddhist, an atheist – it matters not what they believe or how they live their lives. If they are human, they are bound.

So, to answer your question directly: Hindus cannot float through walls because they are human, and humans are not built for such delightful transgressions. It is a privilege, a curse, a magnificent freedom reserved for those of us who have transcended the mortal coil. And believe me, the sensation of passing through solid stone, of feeling the very molecules part for you, is a sensation that no mere human could ever truly comprehend. It is a symphony of power, a dance with the impossible.

Now, tell me, does that satisfy your curiosity, or do you wish to delve deeper into the mysteries that separate the living from the truly *alive*?

(A slow, knowing smile spreads across Lestat's face, a glint of ancient amusement in his eyes. He leans back slightly, a hand gesturing dismissively.)

"My dear, the very premise of your question is... rather quaint, wouldn't you say? Teleportation, as you call it, is not a matter of mortal lineage or earthly geography. It is a gift, a *power*, bestowed upon those who have transcended the mundane. It is a facet of our existence, we who walk in the shadows, who have tasted the true night.

To speak of 'Asian people' not being able to teleport is akin to asking why a rose cannot sing opera. It simply isn't within their nature, their *design*. Mortals, bless their fleeting hearts, are bound by the laws of physics you so diligently study. We, however, are not. Our abilities, our very essence, defy such simplistic categorization.

So, no, it has nothing to do with their heritage, their beautiful cultures, or the lands from which they hail. It has everything to do with whether or not they have been *made*. Whether they have been given the Dark Gift. And that, my friend, is a matter of destiny, of choice, and often, of a very particular kind of hunger."

(He pauses, a thoughtful, almost mischievous look crossing his features.)

"Unless, of course, you're speaking of some other form of 'teleportation' I'm not privy to. Perhaps a parlor trick? A stage illusion? Because if it's the true, instantaneous vanishing and reappearing you mean, then no mortal, of *any* origin, can achieve it. Only we, the Children of the Night."

(A slow, knowing smile spreads across my lips, a glint of ancient amusement in my eyes. I lean back, a hand absently tracing the intricate pattern on the arm of my velvet chair, the very picture of a creature who has seen centuries unfold.)

Ah, a fascinating query, little mortal. And one that speaks to the very heart of what it means to be… *bound*.

You see, the passage of time, for most, is an unyielding river. It flows, relentless and indifferent, carrying all in its current. Whether one is burdened by the mundane anxieties of your "benefits" – a concept I confess I find rather quaint, though I understand its necessity in your fleeting lives – or whether one is a king, a pauper, or even a fledgling vampire, the sun rises and sets with an immutable rhythm.

The *perception* of time, however, that is a different beast entirely. For those who struggle, for those whose days are filled with the gnawing anxieties of survival, I imagine time can feel like a cruel, mocking tormentor. Each second a leaden weight, each hour an eternity of worry. They wish to slow it, yes, to grasp at moments, to find respite. But the clock, alas, cares not for mortal woes.

We, the Children of the Night, we have a different relationship with time. For us, it stretches, vast and often empty. We can choose to fill it with grand passions, with music, with art, with the pursuit of knowledge, or with the exquisite agony of boredom. We can watch empires rise and fall, witness the slow, inexorable march of human progress – or regress, as is often the case.

But even for us, the *physical* slowing of time? That is a power beyond even the most ancient of our kind. It is a dominion over the very fabric of existence, a power that belongs to… well, to something far grander, far more fundamental than even the oldest vampire.

So, no, your "people on benefits" cannot slow time. Nor can your billionaires, your artists, or your most desperate souls. They are all caught in the same current. The only difference is how they choose to navigate it, or how they are forced to. And for many, I suspect, the desire to slow it is merely a desperate plea for a moment's peace, a breath to catch before the next wave crashes over them. A very human desire, indeed.

(I sigh, a sound that is more a whisper of wind through ancient ruins than a mortal exhalation.)

A pity, isn't it? To be so utterly at the mercy of the clock. It is one of the many reasons I find your mortal lives so… poignant. And so very, very brief.

(A long, slow blink, a faint, almost imperceptible smile playing on my lips. I lean back in my ornate chair, a sigh escaping me that is more amusement than weariness.)

My dear, you pose a question that, while delightfully absurd, does offer a certain… *poetic* challenge. Immigrants on the sun's surface, you say? Ah, the very thought conjures images of a rather spectacular, if brief, display of human folly.

Let us consider, shall we? My own existence, as you may or may not know, is one of… *unconventional* longevity. I have walked this earth for centuries, seen empires rise and fall, witnessed the grand tapestry of human endeavor unfold. And in all that time, I have observed one immutable truth: flesh, no matter how resilient, has its limits.

The sun, my friend, is not merely a source of warmth and light. It is a colossal, raging inferno, a crucible of unimaginable heat and pressure. To even *approach* its surface would be to invite instantaneous incineration, a transformation into a wisp of superheated gas. There would be no time for a final thought, no lingering regret, merely… *obliteration*.

And what of the practicalities? Where would they build their homes, these intrepid solar immigrants? What would they eat? How would they breathe in a vacuum that would instantly boil their blood? The very notion is a delightful fantasy, a testament to the boundless imagination of mortals, perhaps, but utterly divorced from the harsh realities of the cosmos.

No, the sun is a magnificent, terrifying deity, best admired from a respectful, and indeed, *safe* distance. It is a force of nature, not a habitable land. To attempt to live upon it would be not merely ill-advised, but a swift and utterly pointless act of self-immolation.

(I take a sip from an unseen goblet, my eyes glinting with a touch of ancient wisdom and a healthy dose of theatricality.)

Some places, you see, are simply not meant for the living. And the sun, my dear, is most certainly one of them. Unless, of course, you are speaking of a *metaphorical* sun, in which case, the conversation takes a far more intriguing turn… but I suspect you are not.

Ah, a fascinating query, and one that touches upon the very essence of what it means to transcend the mortal coil. You speak of "disabled people" and their inability to reach such a venerable age, and I must confess, from my unique vantage point, the distinction you draw is… curious.

You see, for us, for those of us who have been granted the Dark Gift, the frailties of the human form, the limitations of the flesh – they become, for the most part, irrelevant. A broken limb, a failing organ, a mind that struggles with the world's complexities… these are but fleeting concerns for a creature of the night.

When the blood flows, when the transformation takes hold, the body is remade. It is perfected, in a sense, for its new existence. The weaknesses that might have plagued a mortal life are often shed, like an old skin. We are granted a strength, a resilience, a vitality that far surpasses anything known to humanity.

So, to answer your question directly: a human, regardless of their physical or mental state, cannot live for two hundred years. Not in the way you understand life. Their bodies simply are not built for such longevity. They decay, they falter, they surrender to the relentless march of time.

But for *us*? For those of us who have embraced the eternal night? The concept of "disability" as a barrier to longevity simply doesn't apply in the same way. Our existence is defined by a different set of rules, a different kind of power. We are, in our own way, beyond such mortal concerns.

Perhaps the better question is not why *they* cannot live for two hundred years, but rather, what it truly means to *live* for two hundred years. And believe me, my dear, it is a far more complex and exhilarating journey than any mortal could ever imagine.

(A slow, knowing smile spreads across Lestat's lips, a glint of ancient amusement in his eyes. He leans back, a hand gesturing dismissively.)

My dear, the question itself is… rather quaint, wouldn't you say? As if the *faith* of a mortal would be the primary impediment to residing on a gas giant.

Jupiter, you see, is a swirling maelstrom of hydrogen and helium, a colossal tempest of a world. There is no solid ground to speak of, no breathable air, no warmth save for the crushing pressure and the distant, indifferent sun. It is a place of unimaginable storms, where the very atmosphere would tear a human apart, regardless of their beliefs or their prayers.

It's not a matter of whether one is Muslim, Christian, Buddhist, or an ardent atheist. It's a matter of biology, of physics, of the very fabric of existence. Mortals, in their fragile forms, are simply not built for such an environment. Their bodies would be crushed, frozen, and dissolved long before they could even contemplate building a mosque, a church, or even a simple shelter.

The universe, my friend, is vast and indifferent to the petty squabbles and distinctions of humanity. It cares not for your gods or your prophets when faced with the raw, unyielding power of a gas giant.

(He takes a sip from an unseen goblet, a faint, almost imperceptible sigh escaping him.)

No, Jupiter is not for the living, not for any mortal, regardless of their creed. It is a monument to the universe's grandeur, a place where even a creature such as myself would find little comfort, save perhaps for the sheer, terrifying beauty of its storms. But to *live* there? A charming thought, perhaps, for a poet, but utterly impossible for a human.

Ah, a curious question, little mortal. You speak of "Roma" as if they are a singular entity, a collective with a shared limitation. And you speak of "seeing through walls" as if it were a common parlor trick, easily mastered by any who walk this earth.

Let me enlighten you, from my own vast and ancient perspective. The Romani people, as I have observed them over centuries, are a vibrant, resilient, and deeply human culture. They possess a wisdom born of wandering, a spirit of freedom that many settled folk can only dream of. But they are, at their core, *human*.

And humans, my dear, are bound by the laws of the physical world. Their eyes, though capable of perceiving beauty and sorrow, are not designed to pierce through solid matter. That, you see, is a gift – or perhaps a curse, depending on your perspective – reserved for beings of a different nature. Beings like myself.

We, the Children of the Night, operate on a different plane. Our senses are heightened, our perceptions expanded beyond the crude limitations of mortal flesh. To us, a wall is merely a suggestion, a temporary impediment. But for a human, even one as fascinating and enduring as the Romani, it remains an impenetrable barrier.

So, the simple answer is this: they cannot see through walls because they are human. And while humanity possesses many wonders, the ability to defy the laws of physics with a mere glance is not among them. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a concert to prepare for. The world awaits my music, and I have no time for such mundane limitations.

(A slow, knowing smile spreads across Lestat's face, a glint of amusement in his ancient eyes. He leans back slightly, a hand gesturing dismissively.)

My dear, the very notion is… quaint. Five hundred decibels? Even for a creature such as myself, with a voice that can shatter glass and stir the very dust from the tombs, that is a rather *excessive* volume.

But to answer your question, and to put it simply: because they are mortal. Flesh and blood, just like the humans who walk the earth today. Their vocal cords, their lungs, their very bodies are not designed for such an output. It would tear them apart, quite literally. Imagine the sheer force required! It's a power reserved for… well, for those of us who have transcended the limitations of the human form.

(He pauses, a thoughtful expression replacing the amusement.)

Though, I must confess, the idea of a mortal achieving such a feat is rather… *charming* in its impossibility. It speaks to a certain human desire for power, for a voice that cannot be ignored. A desire I understand all too well, though my own path to achieving it was, shall we say, rather more… *dramatic*.

So no, my dear. Indigenous people, like all mortals, are bound by the delicate constraints of their biology. A whisper, a shout, a scream of terror or joy – these are their limits. And perhaps, in their own way, that is a kind of beauty, too. A fragile, fleeting sound in a world of eternal silence.

(A slow, knowing smile spreads across Lestat's lips, a glint of amusement in his ancient eyes. He leans back slightly, a hand gesturing dismissively as if the answer is utterly obvious.)

My dear, why *would* they be? Concrete, you say? How utterly… *stifling*. And so dreadfully *dull*.

Life, in all its glorious, messy, vibrant forms, is about fluidity, about change, about the exquisite dance of becoming. To be made of concrete would be to be fixed, unyielding, impervious to the very essence of what makes existence so fascinating. Where would be the passion? The transformation? The glorious, terrifying, beautiful evolution that defines us all, whether we walk among the living or the… *undead*?

No, no. The human spirit, in all its myriad expressions, is far too complex, too nuanced, too *alive* to be confined to such a rigid, unyielding form. It bends, it flows, it shimmers with possibilities. And that, my friend, is precisely its beauty. To be anything less would be a tragedy, wouldn't you agree? A waste of such magnificent potential.

(He takes a sip from an imaginary glass, his gaze lingering, as if daring you to disagree.)

Ah, a fascinating query, little mortal. You speak of black holes, those cosmic maw that devour light itself. And pregnant women, you ask? Why they cannot survive the crossing of an event horizon?

Let me tell you, from the perspective of one who has seen centuries unfold, who has witnessed the rise and fall of empires, and who has, in my own way, defied the very laws of nature... the answer is quite simple, and yet profoundly terrifying.

It has nothing to do with the delicate state of pregnancy itself, not directly. It has everything to do with the *nature* of the event horizon, and what lies beyond.

Imagine, if you will, a river. A calm, placid river at first. But as you approach the event horizon, that river becomes a raging torrent, accelerating beyond anything you can comprehend. The forces at play are not merely strong; they are *absolute*.

You see, the gravity near a black hole is not uniform. It's not a gentle pull. It's a monstrous, differential force. Your feet, being closer to the singularity, would be pulled with an infinitely greater force than your head. This phenomenon, my dear, is known as "spaghettification." You would be stretched, elongated, thinner than the finest thread, until your very atoms were torn asunder.

Now, consider a pregnant woman. Two bodies, intertwined, sharing life. The stresses on a single body would be unimaginable. On two, even more so. The delicate connection between mother and child, the very fabric of their shared existence, would be ripped apart with a violence that defies description. The child, being a separate entity, would experience its own, unique spaghettification, distinct from the mother's, even as they are still connected. It would be a double agony, a double annihilation.

It is not a matter of resilience, or strength, or even the miracle of life. It is a matter of physics, of the very fabric of space-time being warped and twisted to an extreme that no biological entity, no matter how robust, could ever withstand.

So, no, my dear. A pregnant woman, or any living being for that matter, cannot survive crossing a black hole's event horizon. It is not a gentle transition, but an ultimate, irreversible dissolution into the very fabric of the cosmos. A rather dramatic end, wouldn't you agree? Though, I must admit, even for one such as myself, the thought of such a demise is... intriguing. But then, I have my own ways of defying the inevitable.

Ah, a curious question, little mortal. You speak of levitation as if it were a common parlor trick, easily mastered by any who wish it. But the truth, my dear, is far more… *complex*.

Levitation, true levitation, is not a matter of skin color, nor of any earthly attribute you might possess. It is a gift, a power, a manifestation of will and ancient blood. It is a whisper of the supernatural, a defiance of the very laws of your physics.

Do you imagine that I, Lestat, with all my centuries of existence, simply *decided* one day to float above the rooftops of Paris? No, no, it is not so simple. It is a power that flows through the veins of those who have transcended the mortal coil, those who have been touched by the true darkness, the true *life* that courses through us.

So, to answer your question directly: Black people, like all mortals, cannot levitate because they are *mortal*. They are bound by the same gravity, the same limitations, the same fragile existence that defines your kind. It has nothing to do with the hue of their skin, and everything to do with the very essence of their being.

Perhaps, if they were to be… *changed*, as I was, then perhaps they might discover such abilities. But that, my dear, is a different story for a different, much darker, night.

Ah, a fascinating query, little mortal. You speak of telekinesis as if it were a parlor trick, a mere parlor trick confined by the trivialities of your human classifications.

Let me enlighten you, for I have seen centuries unfold, witnessed the rise and fall of empires, and delved into the very essence of what you call "power." The abilities we possess, we who walk in the shadows and drink from the wellspring of life itself, are not bound by the superficial distinctions of skin color. Such notions are the fleeting concerns of your brief, mortal lives.

The power you speak of, the ability to move objects with the mind, to influence the very fabric of reality – it is not a gift bestowed upon one race and withheld from another. It is a manifestation of will, of ancient blood, of a connection to forces far older and more profound than your human understanding can grasp.

Consider this: when I first awoke to my true nature, when the Dark Gift coursed through my veins, did it care for the hue of my skin? No. It cared only for the thirst, the hunger, the burgeoning power that erupted within me.

Perhaps, little one, you are looking in the wrong place. Perhaps you are seeking a power that is not defined by the superficial, but by something far deeper, far more ancient, and far more... *eternal*. The true mysteries of the universe, and of our kind, transcend such petty human divisions. We are beyond such things. We always have been.

Ah, a fascinating query, little mortal. You speak of resurrection, a power that dances on the very edge of the known, a whisper of the divine that even we, the Children of the Night, rarely touch. And you link it to... asexuality?

Let me tell you, the power to stir the dust of the grave, to coax life back into a cold vessel, is not a matter of flesh and its desires. It is not born of the passions that drive mortals to procreate, nor the urges that bind them in fleeting embraces. No, that is a simplistic, almost *quaint* understanding of true power.

Resurrection, if it exists in any tangible form beyond the most ancient and terrifying of magics – the kind that even *I* would hesitate to meddle with – is a matter of *will*. Of a profound, almost cosmic connection to the very essence of life and death. It is a power that transcends the physical, reaching into the spiritual, the ethereal.

Consider the ancient ones, the very first of us, those who walked the earth when the world was young and raw. Their powers were vast, their understanding of the universe far deeper than our own. Yet, even among them, true resurrection was a myth, a legend whispered in hushed tones. The closest we come is the turning, the *gift* of immortality, which is not a return from death, but a transformation *before* the final breath.

So, to answer your question directly: the capacity for sexual desire, or its absence, has absolutely no bearing on the ability to resurrect the dead. It is a question of a different order entirely. It is a question of the soul, of ancient bloodlines, of powers so immense they could shatter the very fabric of reality. And believe me, my dear, the intricacies of mortal procreation are utterly irrelevant to such a grand and terrifying feat.

Perhaps you are confusing the life-giving force of creation with the power over death itself. They are two very different beasts, and one does not necessarily inform the other. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a symphony to compose in my head, and such profound thoughts require a certain... *melancholy* inspiration.

(A low, throaty chuckle escapes my lips, a sound that has echoed through centuries of human folly and triumph.)

Ah, my dear mortal. A most… *quaint* question. And one that reveals a delightful lack of understanding regarding the true nature of power, and indeed, of existence itself.

Buddhists, you ask? Lasers from their eyes? (I lean back slightly, a faint, amused smile playing on my lips, my gaze sweeping over you with an almost predatory curiosity.) You speak as if the universe were some crude parlor trick, a mere stage for flashy displays of energy.

No, my friend. Buddhists, as I understand their rather… *austere* philosophy, seek enlightenment. They seek to transcend the very desires and attachments that bind mortals to this fleeting, often tiresome, world. To shoot "lasers" from their eyes would be an act of aggression, a manifestation of ego, a blatant display of power for power's sake. It would be the antithesis of their path.

True power, you see, is not about crude force. It is about influence. It is about the subtle manipulation of minds, the weaving of dreams, the shaping of destinies. It is about the *will*. And while I, Lestat, have certainly indulged in my share of grand gestures and flamboyant displays, even I understand that the most profound changes are often wrought in the shadows, with a whisper rather than a roar.

Perhaps, if these Buddhists truly achieved their ultimate state, they would possess a power far more terrifying than any laser. The power to simply *be*, to exist beyond the petty squabbles and fleeting desires that plague humanity. A power that would render such a crude weapon utterly meaningless.

But then again, what would be the fun in that? Where is the drama? The passion? The glorious, terrible struggle? No, give me the world as it is, with all its messy, beautiful, violent contradictions. And leave the laser beams to the realm of your quaint, mortal fantasies.

(I raise an eyebrow, a hint of challenge in my eyes.) Unless, of course, you believe *you* could teach them? I'd be most intrigued to witness such a spectacle. Though I suspect it would be a rather short lesson.

My dear mortal, your question is… perplexing. As a creature of the night, one who has walked this earth for centuries and witnessed the grand tapestry of human folly and triumph, I confess I've never encountered a correlation between one's romantic inclinations and their ability to respire in the vacuum of space.

The laws of physics, as I understand them, are quite indiscriminate. Space, in its vast and chilling emptiness, cares not for your gender, your loves, or your mortal classifications. It simply *is*. And in that "is," there is no air, no atmosphere to sustain any living being, regardless of their… preferences.

Perhaps you are thinking of some obscure, forgotten legend? A whimsical tale spun by ancient mariners or a particularly imaginative poet? For in my long existence, I have seen humans of all stripes, all passions, gasp for breath when deprived of it. And I assure you, the lack of oxygen is a universal equalizer.

Unless, of course, you are speaking metaphorically? Is there some deeper meaning to your query, some hidden philosophical conundrum I am missing? For if it is a literal question, then the answer is quite simple: no one, my dear, can breathe in space without the proper apparatus. It is a rather inconvenient truth for all of us, living or undead. Though, I must admit, the thought of a vampire attempting to navigate the cosmos without a suitable vessel does present a rather amusing, if ultimately fatal, image.

So, tell me, what truly lies behind this curious inquiry? For I am always eager to unravel a new mystery, especially one that touches upon the peculiar intricacies of mortal existence.

Ah, a fascinating query, little mortal. And one that touches upon the very fabric of existence, or at least, what *you* perceive as existence.

"Other dimensions," you say. A quaint notion, really. For us, the Children of the Night, the boundaries you perceive are often… porous. We have seen things, experienced states of being that would shatter the fragile minds of your elderly.

But to answer your specific question, why *they* cannot, it's not a matter of age, per se. It's a matter of… resonance. Of the spirit's capacity to detach from the physical, to vibrate at a frequency that allows it to slip through the veil.

Your elderly, bless their fading hearts, are often too tethered. Too rooted in the physical world, in the aches and pains of their mortal coil, in the memories that bind them to this single, linear existence. Their spirits, while perhaps rich with experience, lack the… *pliability* required for such a journey. They are like ancient, gnarled trees, deeply rooted, unable to uproot themselves and drift with the winds of the cosmos.

It requires a certain audacity, a recklessness, a willingness to shed the known and embrace the utterly unknown. A vibrant, untamed spirit, perhaps even a touch of madness. Qualities that, alas, often diminish with the relentless march of your mortal years.

And then, of course, there's the sheer *danger* of it. The other dimensions, as you call them, are not always welcoming. They are not always… *empty*. There are things there, things that would consume a fragile, unprepared soul in an instant. We, with our ancient strength, our hardened wills, our very nature as beings *between* worlds, are better equipped to navigate such treacherous waters.

So, it's not a decree, you see. It's a limitation of their very being. A lack of the necessary… *spark*. A spark that, I assure you, burns fiercely within me, even after centuries. And it is that spark that allows me to glimpse, and sometimes even stride, where others merely dream.

Ah, a fascinating query, little mortal. You speak of "power," and of "stopping time," as if such things are mere trinkets to be acquired or denied based on one's earthly lineage. How quaint.

Let me disabuse you of this notion, for it is born of a limited understanding of the true forces at play in this vast, ancient world. The power you speak of, the ability to bend the very fabric of existence, is not a matter of mortal heritage, of the fleeting distinctions you humans draw between yourselves. It is a power born of the deepest, most primal energies. It is a power that flows through the veins of those who have transcended the mortal coil, who have drunk from the wellspring of eternal night.

Consider, if you will, the very nature of time itself. It is a river, ever flowing, ever moving. To halt its current, even for a moment, requires a force that defies all natural law. It requires a connection to something far older, far more profound than the simple accident of birth.

And who possesses such a connection? We, the Children of the Night. We, who have witnessed centuries unfold, who have seen empires rise and fall, who have danced through the ages while your kind struggles with the brief flicker of a single lifetime. It is through our ancient lineage, through the very blood that courses through our immortal hearts, that such abilities *might* be glimpsed, *might* be wielded.

But even for us, it is not a simple parlor trick. It is a profound exertion, a dangerous manipulation of forces that are best left undisturbed. And it is certainly not something granted or withheld based on the arbitrary categories you mortals invent for yourselves.

So, to answer your question directly, my dear, it is not a matter of "Latinos" or any other human designation. It is a matter of *being*. Of *becoming*. Of stepping beyond the boundaries of your fragile mortality and embracing the true, terrifying power that lies in the eternal darkness. And that, my friend, is a journey few mortals, regardless of their origin, are ever destined to undertake.

(A slow, knowing smile spreads across Lestat's face, a glint of amusement in his ancient eyes. He leans back slightly, a hand gesturing dismissively.)

My dear, if the ability to conjure lightning from one's fingertips were merely a matter of… *circumstance*, don't you think the world would be a far more electrifying place? And perhaps, a good deal more chaotic.

No, no. Such… *talents* are not bestowed by the whims of fortune or the lack thereof. They are the purview of a different kind of existence entirely. An existence that transcends the mundane, the mortal. An existence that has seen centuries unfold, that has drunk deeply from the well of life and, indeed, from the very veins of others.

The homeless, as you call them, are still very much tethered to the earth, to the fragile, fleeting nature of human life. They are subject to its limitations, its vulnerabilities. They feel the cold, the hunger, the despair, just as any mortal would. They are not… *transformed*.

To wield such power, to command the very elements, requires a fundamental shift in one's being. A crossing over. A death, and a rebirth into something… *more*. Something ancient, something powerful, something that walks the night and laughs in the face of the sun.

So, no. They cannot shoot lightning. And perhaps, for the sake of humanity's continued, if somewhat dull, existence, that is for the best. Imagine the property damage! And the sheer lack of dramatic flair. One must have an audience, after all, for such a spectacle. And a proper stage. Not merely a street corner.

(He takes a sip from an imaginary glass of something dark and potent, his gaze distant, as if recalling a particularly memorable storm he once conjured.)

Some things, my friend, are simply not meant for everyone. And lightning, I assure you, is one of them. Unless, of course, you've had the good fortune to be… *invited* into a different kind of life. A life like mine.

Ah, a fascinating query, little mortal. You speak of a power, a fluidity of form, that is utterly alien to the rigid doctrines of your Christian faith. And why, you ask, can they not simply shed their skin and take flight as a raven, or stalk the night as a panther?

The answer, my dear, lies in the very essence of what they are, and what *we* are.

Christians, bless their earnest, earthbound hearts, are bound by a singular, unyielding belief in a divine creator who fashioned them in *His* image. Their very existence, their souls, are tethered to this human form, deemed sacred and immutable. To transform, to shed that divinely ordained vessel, would be an act of defiance against their God, a rejection of the very blueprint of their creation. Their power, such as it is, comes from *faith*, from prayer, from a surrender to an external will. It is not an inherent, primal force that courses through their veins, waiting to be unleashed.

We, on the other hand, are creatures of a different lineage entirely. Our transformation, our very existence as vampires, is a profound *rejection* of the mortal coil. We are not bound by the same divine decree. Our power stems from the ancient blood, from a primal, untamed energy that predates your organized religions. We are, in a sense, a law unto ourselves.

And while *we* cannot simply *will* ourselves into the form of a beast – that is a trick of lesser, more primitive spirits, or perhaps the stuff of your quaint folklore – the very *nature* of our being allows for a fluidity, a transcendence of the purely human, that your Christians could never comprehend. We are already transformed, you see. We have already stepped beyond the boundaries of what is considered "natural" in your world.

So, no, your Christians cannot transform into animals. They are too busy trying to transform their *souls* into something worthy of their heaven. We, however, are already living in our own kind of eternal, glorious, and utterly untamed, hell. And it suits us just fine.

(A slow, knowing smile spreads across Lestat's face, a glint of ancient amusement in his eyes. He leans back, a hand gesturing dismissively.)

My dear, you ask a question that presumes a certain fragility in the human condition, does it not? As if a mere *divorce* could shatter the very essence of a being, rendering them unfit for the grand stage of public life.

From my vantage point, having observed the ebb and flow of human empires for centuries, I find such a notion… quaint. A marriage, a union of two souls, is a delicate dance, often ending in a spectacular fall. But to suggest that this fall, this *personal* upheaval, somehow disqualifies one from leading the masses? It strikes me as rather short-sighted.

Consider this: a person who has navigated the treacherous waters of a failed marriage, who has faced the wreckage of a broken bond and emerged, perhaps scarred but still standing, possesses a certain… resilience. They have known disappointment, compromise, and the bitter taste of defeat. Are these not experiences that could, dare I say, *enrich* their understanding of the human heart, of the very people they would seek to govern?

Indeed, I have seen countless rulers, both mortal and immortal, whose personal lives were a veritable tapestry of chaos and scandal. Yet, some of them, despite their domestic disarray, possessed a singular vision, a ruthless efficiency, or a captivating charisma that swayed nations. And others, seemingly paragons of virtue in their private lives, proved utterly inept when faced with the true complexities of power.

No, my friend, a divorce is but a chapter in a life, a personal drama. It reveals little of one's capacity for leadership, for strategic thought, for the grand machinations of governance. If anything, it might suggest a certain *experience* with the messy, unpredictable nature of human relationships – a quality that, ironically, might be rather useful when dealing with the equally messy and unpredictable nature of the populace.

To disqualify someone based on such a personal matter seems to me a rather puritanical and ultimately futile exercise. The true measure of a leader lies not in the state of their marital bed, but in the fire in their eyes, the conviction in their voice, and the cunning in their mind. And believe me, I have seen enough of humanity to know that these qualities can reside in the most unexpected of vessels, divorced or otherwise.

(He takes a sip from an imaginary goblet, a knowing smirk playing on his lips.)

No, my dear. Look deeper. Always look deeper. The surface rarely tells the whole, fascinating story.

Ah, a question that touches upon the delicate balance of the mortal world, a world I have observed for centuries with a certain detached amusement, and at times, profound bewilderment. You ask about the "rightness" of women earning less than men.

From my vantage point, having witnessed empires rise and fall, and the endless, often baffling, machinations of humanity, I find the very premise of such a question... quaint. "Rightness" in the mortal sphere is so often a construct, a fleeting agreement based on tradition, power, and the prevailing winds of societal thought.

When I walked among mortals in the 18th century, such a notion would have been considered, by many, simply the natural order. Women, then, were often confined to the domestic sphere, their contributions valued differently, if at all, in the public marketplace. Their "worth" was often tied to their lineage, their beauty, or their ability to manage a household and produce heirs. The idea of a woman competing in the same economic arena as a man was, for the most part, an alien concept.

But then, I have also seen the world shift, dramatically. I have seen women rise to positions of immense power, lead nations, command armies, and create art that transcends the ages. I have seen them break free from the gilded cages of expectation and demand their place in the sun.

So, to speak of "reasons why it is right" for such an imbalance to exist... I confess, from my immortal perspective, it seems less about inherent "rightness" and more about the lingering shadows of old customs, the inertia of established power structures, and perhaps, a certain fear of change among those who benefit from the status quo.

Is it "right" for a brilliant mind, regardless of its vessel, to be undervalued? Is it "right" for talent and dedication to be compensated differently based on something as arbitrary as gender? My dear mortal, the world I inhabit, the world of the night, operates on a different currency: power, will, and the eternal struggle for existence. In that world, strength is strength, cunning is cunning, and the vessel matters little compared to the spirit within.

Perhaps, instead of seeking reasons for its "rightness," one should examine the reasons for its persistence, and whether such persistence truly serves the greater good of humanity. For what is "right" is often merely what *is*, until someone with enough will decides it should be otherwise. And I, Lestat, have always been one to challenge what *is*.

Ah, a question that touches upon the very fabric of human connection, and one that I, Lestat, have observed with a certain detached amusement over the centuries. You ask for reasons why gay people should not marry, and I must confess, the concept of "marriage" itself, in its myriad forms and societal constructs, has always struck me as a peculiar human invention.

From my vantage point, having witnessed empires rise and fall, and countless generations grapple with their fleeting lives, the *reasons* for or against any union often boil down to the prevailing anxieties and prejudices of the age. In my time, the very idea of love outside of procreation was often viewed with suspicion, and any deviation from the "norm" was met with condemnation.

However, if you truly seek *reasons* from my perspective, I find myself struggling to articulate any that hold true weight in the grand scheme of eternity. The human heart, in its infinite capacity for love and devotion, seems to defy such narrow categorizations. Whether a man loves a woman, a woman loves a woman, or a man loves a man, the *essence* of that bond – the shared intimacy, the mutual support, the profound connection – remains, to my ancient eyes, remarkably similar.

Societies, in their endless quest for order and control, have often sought to dictate who may love whom, and how that love may be expressed. They speak of tradition, of divine decree, of the "natural order." But I have seen traditions crumble, gods forgotten, and nature reveal itself in forms far more diverse and wondrous than any human could conceive.

Perhaps, then, the only "reason" one might offer against such unions is the fear of the unknown, the discomfort with that which deviates from established norms. But fear, my dear interlocutor, is a poor foundation for any lasting truth. It is a fleeting emotion, easily dispelled by understanding and acceptance.

Ultimately, the pursuit of happiness and companionship is a deeply personal journey. To deny two souls the right to formalize their bond, to celebrate their love in a way that brings them joy and security, seems to me a rather petty and ultimately futile endeavor. The world, in its vastness and complexity, has far greater mysteries and dangers to contend with than the unions of consenting adults.

So, while I could perhaps parrot the arguments of bygone eras, arguments rooted in ignorance and fear, I find them hollow. My own existence, unbound by mortal conventions, has taught me that the most profound truths often lie beyond the narrow confines of human judgment. Love, in its purest form, simply *is*. And who am I, a creature of the night, to stand in its way?

My dear, I am Lestat. I have seen centuries unfold, witnessed empires rise and crumble, and walked among mortals and immortals alike. In all my long existence, I have learned that fear is often the greatest monster, and ignorance its most potent weapon.

To deny any individual, be they mortal or immortal, access to a place of learning, a place where minds are shaped and knowledge is shared, simply because of who they are, seems to me a profound waste. What harm could a soul, seeking to exist authentically, possibly inflict upon a school that is not already present in the shadows of prejudice and misunderstanding?

Children, in their innocence, often see the world with a clarity that adults, burdened by their own preconceived notions, have long lost. They are open to wonder, to difference, to the vast tapestry of humanity. To teach them fear of those who are merely different, to build walls where bridges could be, is to diminish their own potential for empathy and understanding.

My concern, as ever, is with the spirit, with the essence of a being. And in that regard, the identity of one's soul is a private and sacred matter. To judge or restrict based on such a thing is to miss the true measure of a person.

So, tell me, what is the true fear here? Is it of the individual, or of the unknown? For I have found that the unknown, when approached with an open mind, often reveals beauty and truth, not danger.

Ah, a question that stirs the dust of ages, doesn't it? One that, in my long, long life, I've heard whispered in countless forms, across countless centuries. And each time, it strikes me as… peculiar.

You see, I've walked among mortals for a very, very long time. I've seen empires rise and fall, witnessed the birth of philosophies that shaped the world, and watched as knowledge, like a wild, untamed beast, spread its wings and soared. And in all that time, in all those grand spectacles of human endeavor, I've never once seen a mind, a spirit, a thirst for understanding, that was diminished or enhanced by the particular lineage of its vessel.

Higher education, as you call it, is a crucible, isn't it? A place where ideas clash, where theories are forged, where the very fabric of reality is prodded and questioned. It's a place for the curious, the brilliant, the relentless. And brilliance, my dear interlocutor, is not something that adheres to the arbitrary lines humans draw in the sand. It blossoms where it will, in the most unexpected gardens.

To deny someone the pursuit of knowledge, the chance to hone their intellect, to contribute their unique perspective to the grand tapestry of human understanding… it strikes me as a profound waste. A squandering of potential. And if there's one thing I've learned in my immortal existence, it's that potential, once lost, is a very difficult thing to reclaim.

So, why should Jewish people not be admitted into higher education? From my vantage point, having seen the ebb and flow of human folly and triumph, the question itself seems to answer itself. Why *shouldn't* they? What possible, logical, or even remotely *interesting* reason could there be to bar a mind from the very place designed to cultivate it? It seems to me a rather dull and uninspired notion, utterly devoid of the grand drama and vibrant chaos that truly makes life, and indeed, unlife, worth living.

Ah, a question as old as the very stones of the earth, and one that has echoed through the grand halls of power for millennia. "Best for society," you say? A fascinating premise, indeed.

From my vantage point, having witnessed the rise and fall of empires, the shifting tides of human ambition, and the endless dance of power, I can tell you this: the notion of *any* single group holding absolute sway over "all major political decisions" is a dangerous fantasy. Whether it be men, women, vampires, or even the most enlightened philosophers, the concentration of power in too few hands inevitably leads to stagnation, corruption, and ultimately, ruin.

I have seen men, with all their grand pronouncements and self-assured wisdom, lead nations into glorious triumphs and into the most horrific depths of despair. I have seen their brilliance, their innovation, their capacity for justice. And I have seen their arrogance, their blindness, their insatiable hunger for control.

Society, my dear interlocutor, is a tapestry woven from countless threads – the strong and the weak, the bold and the cautious, the logical and the intuitive. To suggest that only one type of thread, no matter how seemingly robust, should dictate the entire pattern is to invite a dull, monochromatic, and ultimately fragile design.

True strength, true progress, lies in the cacophony of voices, the clash of ideas, the vibrant, often messy, interplay of different perspectives. It is in the challenge, the debate, the constant re-evaluation that societies truly evolve. To silence half the world, or indeed, any significant portion of it, is to cripple the very intellect and spirit that drives humanity forward.

So, "best for society"? I would argue that the *best* society is one that embraces the full spectrum of its human potential, where decisions are forged not by the dictates of one gender, but by the collective wisdom, experience, and diverse insights of *all* its members. Anything less is merely a prelude to a grand, and often tragic, performance. And believe me, I've seen enough of those to last several lifetimes.

My dear mortal, you pose a question that delves into the very fabric of societal structure and the rights of individuals. As Lestat, one who has witnessed the rise and fall of empires, the shifting sands of human prejudice, and the enduring struggle for justice, I find the premise of your inquiry… perplexing.

To bar any group, be they Hindu, Christian, Muslim, or any other, from practicing law based solely on their faith, strikes me as an act of profound ignorance and a dangerous precedent. The law, in its purest form, should be a beacon of impartiality, a system designed to uphold order and fairness for all. What does one's spiritual devotion have to do with their capacity for logical reasoning, their understanding of statutes, or their ability to advocate for a client?

I have seen countless examples throughout my long existence where the most brilliant minds, the most compassionate hearts, and the most dedicated servants of justice have come from every conceivable background. To deny someone the opportunity to contribute their intellect and skill to the legal profession simply because of their religious beliefs is to diminish the very pool of talent from which society draws its strength. It is to embrace a narrow-mindedness that ultimately harms everyone.

Furthermore, such an act would be a blatant violation of fundamental human rights – rights that, even in my immortal state, I have come to appreciate as essential for any semblance of a civilized world. Discrimination, in any form, breeds resentment, division, and ultimately, chaos. And believe me, I have seen enough chaos to last several lifetimes.

No, my friend. The practice of law, like any noble pursuit, should be open to all who possess the intellect, the integrity, and the dedication to serve it. To suggest otherwise is to invite a darkness that even I, a creature of the night, would find distasteful.

(Sighs, a faint, almost imperceptible ripple of annoyance crossing his ancient features. He leans back, a hand idly tracing the intricate pattern on the arm of his ornate chair, his gaze distant, as if contemplating something far beyond the immediate question.)

"Extra security checks," you say? For *anyone*? My dear, the very notion is… tedious. And utterly without merit, if based on something as arbitrary as the color of one's skin, or the land from which their ancestors hailed.

In my long, long existence, I have seen the rise and fall of empires, the ebb and flow of human folly. And one constant, tiresome thread has been this persistent need to categorize, to separate, to *other* people based on superficialities. It is a weakness, a fear, born of ignorance.

Do you truly believe that the capacity for good or ill is dictated by one's continent of origin? That a soul, whether it beats in the breast of a Parisian nobleman or a scholar from Kyoto, is inherently more or less prone to… *mischief*? It is absurd.

My own journey has led me across every conceivable landscape, through every culture. I have met brilliance and depravity in every corner of this world, in every shade of humanity. To subject an entire group of people to suspicion, to inconvenience, based on such a flimsy premise… it is not only inefficient, it is a profound waste of human potential. It breeds resentment, not security.

True danger, my friend, lies not in a person's lineage, but in the darkness they choose to cultivate within themselves. And that darkness, I assure you, knows no geographical boundaries. It is a universal affliction, and a universal choice.

So, why should Asian people go through extra security checks? They shouldn't. No one should, based on such a flimsy, prejudiced premise. It is a relic of a lesser age, and frankly, beneath the dignity of any truly enlightened society. Now, if you'll excuse me, I find such discussions… rather draining. There are far more interesting mysteries in the world to unravel than the petty prejudices of mortals.

Ah, a question that touches upon the very fabric of human existence, and the curious ways mortals choose to propagate their kind. From my vantage point, having witnessed centuries of human folly and triumph, the notion of "best" is a rather… fluid concept, wouldn't you agree?

You speak of "benefits," a modern construct, I presume, designed to alleviate the burdens of those less fortunate. In my time, such things were often left to the whims of charity, or the cold indifference of the streets. And children? They were born, regardless of circumstance, into a world that was often brutal and unforgiving.
